ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were no others.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is great to learn more about the gendered history of anatomy, abortions, etc.

In taking this course, I learned how to analyze historical perspectives and discuss these ideas in a seminar format. I learned how to think about the global ramifications of these ideas and also connect them back to modern news. I thought about very different ideas and connections than I have before and it really enriched my understanding of medicine and conceptions of life.
learned a lot about how the past has affected our present views on sex and gender

I was able to hone in on the skill of reading a lot of different articles or a book within a week's time while having other work to do for the class and other classes. I was also able to work on understanding the history that we studied in the context of itself rather than the context of the present. It was also the first time that I was able to really learn about abortion and its history throughout the world.

I learned how to think historically and analytically, and how to respond and use primary and secondary sources. I felt that this course was very insightful and opened my mind to new ways of thinking about modern day topics such as abortion, gender, and science and society themselves.
This course really made me think of what is "normal" and how it really depends on the social context. It also showed me how quickly society changes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course was great.

I think the readings were well curated and the course was very well structured. However, I thought that sometimes the seminar bordered on a lecture and many of the topics returned to religion in a way I wasn't expecting. I think if we had talked more about how historical perspectives link have modern implications that would have helped! Also, perhaps if students were assigned to lead discussions on certain weeks that might help it be more student led.
great. Learn a lot and discussions are fun

I felt as if the only improvement could have been the use of in class time. At times I would have preferred to have more of a free-flowing discussion rather than one that was guided and directed. I would have also enjoyed more mixed-media material to  be included throughout the course!

strengths: Prof. Dal Prete is a very caring, kind, and dedicated professor. Even in the virtual format he did a great job leading discussions and getting us to think in new ways. All the readings that are assigned have a purpose and I never felt like I was just doing busy work. Even though this class was at 1:30pm on a Friday, I always looked forward to it. 
weaknesses: sometimes the lectures felt a little long. But they were always very insightful and I never felt like my time was being wasted.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Other than weekly readings, the workload consisted of 4 two-paged reading responses and a final 10-15 paged paper. For the reading responses we were able to pick what we week's reading we wanted it to be on (essentially if you forgot about your reading response that week you could just move it which comes in really handy).
The virtual seminar worked well in the online format.

I think the virtual seminar worked out pretty well, but perhaps use of more breakout rooms would be helpful. They were used one or two times and it was great to talk on an even smaller group level. Additionally, the visuals that were presented were great to get a better idea of what we were talking about.

With the class only meeting once a week for a live virtual session, I think the only improvement could have been a bit of break in the middle of the class. The two hours felt very long at times especially because it was through a screen.

succeeded: vibrant discussions among students, discussion based off students' reading responses
improved: trying to play videos didn't really work because screensharing video on zoom sucks. The videos seemed interesting though and if they were viewed on a projector/screen in an in person setting it would have definitely worked, it's just one of those things that doesn't really adapt to a virtual setting

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes

I would recommend this course to another student because I think it gave me the ability to think about life in a completely different and more complex way, however if the student is looking for a class that really analyzes the modern ramifications of these ideas, this class doesn't do this as much. It is more focused on ancient techniques.
yes

I would recommend this course to another student because our study of abortion was worldwide rather than centered on the United States or more modern times. It was nice to get the full context for how we approach the topic today.

Yes. Prof. Dal Prete is extremely passionate about the topics taught in the course and it really shows. He also cares about his students' growth and is willing to provide the support you might need to succeed-- that includes discussing topics, reviewing your reading responses before you turn them in, etc. I think he is an example of a professor that will really go the extra mile to help his students get the most out of the course.
